body: When you run `rspec`, the backtrace line has the full, absolute path to `test.rb`.  When you run `ruby test.rb`, the backtrace line has `test.rb` (without the full, absolute path).  Our [current logic](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/v3.1.7/lib/rspec/core/notifications.rb#L279-L284) looks for the full, absolute path of the example location, so it fails when you run `ruby test.rb`.  However, if you run `ruby /full/path/to/test.rb`, it'll work.  We might be able to improve our logic so that it works for your case without forcing you to pass the absolute file name but I haven't thought that through far enough to figure out how we'd do that.
There's a fix for this in #1829 if you want to give that a shot.  Thanks for the very clear bug description!

Running the patch is a little tricky for me - working on it.

I actually have a more complicated test case than the one I showed you, that was just the smallest case I could get to repro.
Cool, that appears to work! Ship it! :+1:
Out of curiosity, why are you running your specs through ruby and 'rspec/autorun' rather than through the RSpec command?

I run a rather complicated setup at https://coderpad.io - essentially people can run arbitrary ruby code, and I'd like for them to be able to run specs and such in the normal fashion. However, I can't tell from the outside whether a bunch of code is normal ruby code (and meant to be invoked with `ruby`) or spec code that should be invoked with `rspec`.

@myronmarston do you have any tips on how to install the patched `rspec-core` in the meantime? Trying to use a Gemfile with the branch pointed to yours gives me tricky dependency errors.

To test I just manually applied the diff to gem as it lay in the gems directory, which is probably not a great plan.

> @myronmarston do you have any tips on how to install the patched rspec-core in the meantime? Trying to use a Gemfile with the branch pointed to yours gives me tricky dependency errors.

The trick is that you have to use the `master` branch from github for all of the rspec gems if you are going to use it for one of them.  So in your gemfile, you could do:

``` ruby
%w[ core expectations mocks support rails ].each do |lib| # remove rails if you're not using rspec-rails
  gem "rspec-#{lib}", github: "rspec/rspec-#{lib}"
end
```

@myronmarston Cool, that should tide me over for a while. Know when the linked patch will make it to a new release?

Also, thanks for your hard work. Happy new year.

> @myronmarston Cool, that should tide me over for a while. Know when the linked patch will make it to a new release?

Hopefully in the next couple weeks, but no promises.  We're trying to coordinate a few things in tandem with the 3.2 release but hopefully it'll be out soon.
